sen.j: 他人丼（たにんどん、-どんぶり）とは、牛肉もしくは豚肉を、玉ねぎなどと割り下で煮て卵でとじ、丼飯の上に乗せた料理である。
sen.e: Tanin-don or Tanin-donburi is a dish in which beef or pork is boiled with onions and stock mixed with soy sauce, mirin and sugar, mixed with eggs, and placed on donburi meshi (a bowl of boiled rice.)
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文例外対処
sen.e: Tanin-don or tanin-donburi is a dish in which beef or pork that is boiled with onions in a stock mixed with soy sauce, mirin and sugar, stiffened with eggs, and then placed on donburi meshi (a bowl of boiled rice).

Tanin-don or tanin-donburi is a dish in which beef or pork that is boiled with onions in a stock mixed with soy sauce, mirin and sugar, stiffened with eggs, and then placed on donburi meshi (a bowl of boiled rice).
Tanin-don is a kind of Donburimono.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文例外対処
sen.e: Tanin-don is a kind of Donburimono.
Tanin-don is a kind of Donburimono.
Summary
Summary
Summary

sen.j: 基本的には親子丼と同じ調理法を用いて作られる。
sen.e: Tanin-don is basically made using the recipe same as Oyako-don.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文例外対処
sen.e: Tanin-don is basically made using the recipe same as Oyako-don.
Tanin-don is basically made using the recipe same as Oyako-don.

sen.j: 親子丼が鶏の肉と鶏の卵を使うことに対し、鶏肉以外の肉（牛肉・豚肉）を使用する事（他人の肉を使用する）から名づけられた。
sen.e: Oyako-don is made using chicken and eggs, whereas Tanin-don is made using meat except for chicken (beef or pork), (i.e., using meat of a stranger), hence Tanin-don is named.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文例外対処
sen.e: Oyako-don is made using chicken and eggs, whereas tanin-don is made using meat except for chicken (beef or pork), i.e., using meat of a stranger for an egg; hence tanin-don is named after this recipe.

Oyako-don is made using chicken and eggs, whereas tanin-don is made using meat except for chicken (beef or pork), i.e., using meat of a stranger for an egg; hence tanin-don is named after this recipe.

sen.j: 他人丼の具材をかけうどんに乗せた他人うどんもある。
sen.e: There is also Tanin-udon in which the ingredients of Tanin-don is placed on kake-udon (Japanese wheat noodle with broth.)
There is also tanin-udon in which the ingredients of tanin-don are placed on kake-udon (Japanese wheat noodle with broth).
There is also tanin-udon in which the ingredients of tanin-don are placed on kake-udon (Japanese wheat noodle with broth).
Difference of names
Difference in names
Difference in names

sen.j: 主に関西地方では牛肉を使用したのを「他人丼」と呼ぶ。
sen.e: In the Kansai region, Donburimono using beef is mainly called "Tanin-don."
Mainly in the Kansai region, donburimono using beef is called "tanin-don."
sen.cmt: mainlyを文頭に移動。Donburimonoと Tanin-don の先頭を小文字化。
sen.e: Mainly in the Kansai region, donburimono using beef is called "tanin-don."

sen.j: その他の地域の場合、大抵は豚肉を使用したのを指す。
sen.e: In areas except for the Kansai region, "Tanin-don" usually refers to Donburimono using pork.
In areas other than the Kansai region, "tanin-don" usually refers to the donburimono using pork.
In areas other than the Kansai region, "tanin-don" usually refers to the donburimono using pork.

sen.j: 関東地方の場合、牛肉を使用したのを「開化丼」と呼ぶ。
sen.e: In the Kanto region, Donburimono using beef is called "Kaika-don."
In the Kanto region, donburimono using beef is called "kaika-don."
sen.cmt: Donburimonoと Kaika-don の先頭を小文字化。
sen.e: In the Kanto region, donburimono using beef is called "kaika-don."

sen.j: これは牛肉は牛鍋に示されるように文明開化の象徴であり、「他人」とは粗末な呼び方だという考えがあったからである。
sen.e: The reason for this came from the thought that beef was a symbol of the westernization like sukiyaki, and thus the call "Tanin (stragner)" was humble.
The reason for this came from the thought that beef was a symbol of westernization of Japan like sukiyaki, and the call "tanin (stragner)" sounded humble.
The reason for this came from the thought that beef was a symbol of westernization of Japan like sukiyaki, and the call "tanin (stragner)" sounded humble.

sen.j: ただし、店によっては「開化丼」と称しても豚肉を使用したのが出されることもある。
sen.e: However, some restaurants serve "Kaika-don" using pork.
However, some restaurants served kaika-don using pork.
However, some restaurants served kaika-don using pork.

sen.j: これは、開化丼は他人丼の別名と解釈されているからと推測される。
sen.e: The supposed reason for this is that Kaika-don is interpreted as another name for Tanin-don.
A possible reason for this is that kaika-don was interpreted as another name for tanin-don.
A possible reason for this is that kaika-don was interpreted as another name for tanin-don.

sen.j: そもそも「他人丼」という名称は関西が起源である。
sen.e: Primarily, the Kansai region is the birthplace of the name "Tanin-don."
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文例外対処
sen.e: Primarily, the Kansai region is the birthplace of the name "tanin-don."
Primarily, the Kansai region is the birthplace of the name "tanin-don."

sen.j: 関西人の「他人は他人」と割り切った気質が表れている。
sen.e: In this name, a spirit of people in the Kansai region appears that "a stranger is a stranger."
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文例外対処
sen.e: In this name, a spirit of the people in the Kansai region appears saying "a stranger is a stranger."
In this name, a spirit of the people in the Kansai region appears saying "a stranger is a stranger."

sen.j: 吉野家などの牛丼チェーンが関西に進出するまでは、牛肉の丼といえば「他人丼」であった。
sen.e: Donburi with beef has meant "Tanin-don" until Gyu-don (Donburimono with cooked beef on cooked rice) chains such as Yoshinoya came into the Kansai region.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文例外対処
sen.e: Donburi with beef meant "tanin-don" until Gyu-don (donburimono with cooked beef on cooked rice) chains such as Yoshinoya penetrated into the Kansai region.
Donburi with beef meant "tanin-don" until Gyu-don (donburimono with cooked beef on cooked rice) chains such as Yoshinoya penetrated into the Kansai region.

sen.j: 今でも、うどん屋や食堂ではメニューに牛丼がなくても、他人丼はある事が多い。
sen.e: Many noodle shops and restaurants still have menus without Gyu-don but have with Tanin-don.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文例外対処
sen.e: Many noodle shops and restaurants still have menus without Gyu-don but have with Tanin-don.
Many noodle shops and restaurants still have menus without Gyu-don but have with Tanin-don.

sen.j: 地方の食堂では鶏肉を用意する手間の関係で「親子丼」と称して、実際には炒め物に使う豚肉などを利用して「他人丼」が供されることがしばしばある。
sen.e: Restaurant in the country-side often serve "Tanin-don" called "Oyako-don" in which pork is used instead of chicken for stir-fried dishes to save preparing time and effort.
Restaurants in the country side often serve "tanin-don" under tha name of "oyako-don" in which pork used in stir-fried dishes is used instead of chicken to save preparing time and effort.
Restaurants in the country side often serve "tanin-don" under tha name of "oyako-don" in which pork used in stir-fried dishes is used instead of chicken to save preparing time and effort.
